Situation A. Walking at a Constant Rate

Assume you continue to walk at the rate determined in the Initial Challenge
• Write an equation that represents the distance d in meters that you could walk in t seconds. Compare your equation to your classmates’ equations.

• For a walking rate of 2 meters per second, an equation is d = 2t, where d is the distance in meters and t is the time in seconds.
  • For a walking rate of r meters per second, an equation is d = rt, where d is the distance in meters and t is the time in seconds.
• Describe what a graph of your equation would look like. Check your answer by making a graph of your data.
Possible answer: For a walking rate of 2 meters per second: The graph would be a line starting at (0,0). For every 1 second walked, the distance increases by 2.
For a walking rate of r meters per second: The graph would be a line starting at (0,0). For every one second walked, the distance increases by r.
• How do your equation and graph compare to those of your classmates?

Students answers will vary.

Students should be able to talk about seeing the rate in each equation and graph. They may not use words like coefficient or slope, but they know unit rates.

Students might discuss that anyone with the same walking rate has the same equation and graph.

Anyone with faster walking rates will have a larger multiplier (coefficient of the independent variable) in their equation and a steeper/faster-growing line on their graph. The faster the rate, the closer the line is the y-axis.

Anyone with slower walking rates will have a lesser multiplier in their equation and a less steep/ slower-growing line on their graph. The slower the rate, the closer the line is to the x- axis.

Students may mention rate is indicated in the equation by the multiplier/coefficient of the independent variable. The equations will have a common form, d = rt, where d is the distance in meters and t is the time in seconds. In this situation, the rate is a unit rate and the constant of proportionality.

Note: This can be a formative assessment to see if students have held onto these comparison ideas from Comparing and Scaling.

Note: Students were first introduced to the key word coefficient in grade 6 Variables and Patterns. Students will be reintroduced to the keyword in Problem 2.2 of this unit. Students are introduced to slope as a ratio/rate in Problem 4.2.

Situation B. Liz's Strategy

Examine Liz’s strategy. Is she correct? Explain.

Liz’s Strategy

I think walking rates are like ratios. So, I used proportional reasoning to write 'for every' statements to answer the questions in Situation A.

For every

1.5 m per 1 second, I walk

⤹ x5 ⤹ x5

7.5 m in 5 seconds, or

⤹ x2 ⤹ x2

15 m in 10 seconds, …or

⤹ x 33.5 ⤹ x33.5

500 m in about 333 seconds

Sample answer: She is correct. The ratio of meters walked to seconds always stays the same, so, for example, (1.5 meters)/(1 second) = (7.5 meters)/(5 seconds) = (15 meters)/(10 seconds). You can always predict how long it will take to walk a specific distance based on this constant ratio.
